p: The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine experience has shown that country-driven operational research and implementation science are needed to achieve high coverage in non-infant populations. Most countries conducting HPV demonstration projects have implemented school-based programs targeting adolescent girls, and many have also provided the vaccine through health facilities to reach girls who are not in the formal school system. GVIRF participants noted that school-based programs could provide a platform for delivery of additional services to adolescents but must be complemented by programs targeting the 263 million children who are out of school. To facilitate high coverage, social mobilization is needed to increase awareness and reduce vaccine hesitancy [24], [25].
